text: this is adam ellic reporting from
Houston Texas recycling does not come
easy here they don't do recycling in the
neighborhood where we live so I bring my
recycled material here more than half of
Houston's homes don't receive curbside
recycling and 25 thousand households are
waitlisted for the service it takes
Patrick haggar 30 minutes to get to the
city's drop-off facility but most
houstonians don't come at all well I
lived in Boston first and in Austin and
they all had regular recycling programs
there so I was surprised that Houston
didn't have anything Houston may proudly
wear the label of the world's energy
capital but it is also the worst
recycler among the nation's 30 largest
cities at the top of the list of san
francisco which keeps about seventy
percent of its garbage out of landfills
by recycling new york salvages thirty
five percent of its waste but Houston
diverts just 2.5 percent according to
the trade magazine waste news the city
is not helped by its sprawling layout
and cheap landfill prices the question
here in cowboy country is who is to
blame the city or the citizens for
Houston's inability to profit from
recycling
if you want to recycle you can do it to
me it's not a government issue or what
we're doing it's a matter of if our
folks are motivated mayor white
honorable council members thanks for the
opportunity to address you today on the
issue of recycling in Houston we believe
that the current program efforts are
insufficient that they're inferior in
some ways to comparable cities and that
they require additional effort and
resources we've come a long way on
curbside recycling from where we were
four years ago when it was almost
dormant we're going to do more but I
think that our current levels of
recycling are unacceptable the solution
is a source of debate some residents are
calling on the city to mandate recycling
or charge for excess trash analysts say
that would be politically unpopular in
this libertarian heartland the mayor
says the tree recycling program set for
October will boost Houston's rating to
twenty percent by 2010 thirty percent of
the waste stream that we pick up from
residential or trees and grass there's
nothing like that anywhere in the United
States is because we have a twelvemonth
growing season we have yards absolutely
everything you say is right I would I
would only say that that at some point
the council and I think that point
frankly may be here you may have to take
some measure that is perceived as
unpopular and that's happened in many
American cities where you get the small
trash can for free you want a huge one
will have your reduced and we're still
sending a message that says we want a
lot of trash and we want a little bit of
recycling part of the problem may be
money land is cheap in Texas quite
honestly and so it has been easier not
only for Houston but for other cities in
the past to do a cost-benefit analysis
and say recycling calls too much with
recycling commodity prices at an
all-time high national experts say the
landfill excuse is no longer valid they
say Houston needs to raise its
significantly low recycling budget it's
hard to compare us to cities that are
charging $22
only one dollars a month for a customer
that own their own landfills and they
can take that revenues I'm quite
comfortable with where we are the thing
that I am very focused on and certainly
I know that the mayor is focused on what
makes the most sense for Houston as the
city tries to solve its recycling
dilemma the system remains imperfect
that the reason they quit in the
neighborhood where I am is because
nobody utilized the service we can't
have everything we'd like I wish it were
easier but I'm still willing to do
